comment._content: That is a super image!! I have just been listening again to the Forsythe saga and the chapter on the funeral of old Aunt Anne. People were invited to the funeral and there was strict precedence in who went in which carriage. This is really wonderful with the hearse and detail in the coffin!

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: An interesting character. According to Wikipedia he died in England, so doubtless this is the cortege taking his remains from the quayside after repatriation to Ireland for burial. (I know it's 112 years ago, but it still seems disrespectful and am strongly resisting the urge to scan for dogs in this one...)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Descripton in the London Times the following day "The body was enclosed in a polished oak coffin, heavily mounted." [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] The list of chief mourners includes lords, colonels, a viscount, a major-general and a Mr. The wreathes and crosses filled four wagons.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I see Norm (of united parishes of Malahide, Portmarnock and St Doulagh's fame) is the archivist of the IRRS. I must ask him about the sheds when I next see him.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
Abbey (Waterford)
Junction (approx S612127, Irish grid). Line from Waterford to New Ross opened 1904, Dublin, Wicklow & Wexford Railway. Waterford, Abbey Junction (Gaelic Port Láirge Gabhal an Mhainistir) created 1906 with opening of line to Felthouse Junction (near Rosslare), Fishguard and Rosslare Railways & Harbours Company. Line to New Ross closed to passengers 1963, remains open for occasional freight. Line from Waterford to Rosslare remains open. Junction near Abbey Street, which marks the site of an ancient abbey of which just a few ruins remain.

That'd be it.

comment.author: 77199267@N03

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I wonder what Lord Beresford would have thought about the monument to Thomas Francis Meagher which now stands at this spot... maps.google.ie/maps?q=the+mall+waterford&ll=52.260278...

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The arrange ments for the funeral, published in the London Times on 31st Dec 1900 The funeral was due to begin at "12 o'clock noon, or as near thereto as the boat service will permit" Several of the mourners at the funeral were also present at the memorial service at Dorking 24 hours later. It must have been a hectic few days for them. The account of the Dorking memorial service states that Lily, Duchess of Marlborough, "only arrived at Dorking from Ireland at 10.45 am".

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Burial was at Clonegam Church, a tiny place out at Curraghmore.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] The page to the east of it is a bit older; It marks the railway as under construction.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] That funeral notice makes for fascinating reading. Effectively the family helped arrange transit for mourners from England to Ireland. (And back again) Very interesting approach.

 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Not clear whether Beresford was political himself, or a career soldier with no particular leanings, but I can't imagine the broader family would've been particularly approving of that particular statue...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
From his biography p.317 - archive.org/stream/lordwilliamberes00menzuoft#page/316/mo...
" ... Lord William was laid to rest in the family vault at Clonagam [sic] Church, and the whole route from the boat to the Clonagam was wonderful; every little child wanted to pay a last tribute to their friend, the road was packed and lined with those who cared, not sightseers. ... "
"Lord William Beresford, V.C. - Some memories of a famous sportsman, soldier and wit" - Mrs Stuart Menzies (Jenkins, London 1917) [ed.]

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] His lengthy obituary in the Times (London) on Dec 31st confirms that.  "He had never taken any active part in politics, but, like all the members of his family, he was a staunch unionist".

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Meaghar himself had an interesting pedigree - his grandfather was a Tipp man who emigrated to Newfoundland and set up a merchant business shipping between St John's and Waterford. He sent his son back to Waterford to manage the business there and that's where Thomas Francis was born. TFM was educated in Clongowes and later by the Jesuits in England (his father eschewed Trinity due to its perceived anti-Irish & anti-Catholic bias) so he was already quite a cosmopolitan chap by the time of his involvement in the 1848 rebellion.

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: He was not afraid to speak his mind to Queen Victoria,quite the man. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_William_Beresford

comment.author: 16693700@N03
comment._content: Lord William Beresford was another brave Irish recipient of the Victoria Cross. He was known as Fighting Bill, and his Vanity Fair Spy lithograph describes him as such. He raced a horse called Fenian and died from a surfeit of rich game for which his failing constitution was no longer fit. He owned a poodle called Ponto (one for the dog lovers out there),  and was a member of the Calcutta Tent Club which promoted the art and sport of pig sticking. Incidentally the photograph of the wreaths at his funeral referred to above does not do justice to the 4 cartloads of tributes that followed the procession. As Mrs Stuart Menzies asked in her biography "Shall we ever see his like again?"

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/16693700@N03] Mrs Stuart Menzies' book is full of delightful anecdotes. Here is the bit about receiving the VC from Queen Victoria, followed by a prank cold shower on another army officer in the Bilton Hotel, Dublin. - archive.org/stream/lordwilliamberes00menzuoft#page/90/mod...
